description: More than 100 people turned out Sunday afternoon for an quickly-organized march through Uptown Roxboro to protest the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis and to prove that Roxboro residents can protest injustice without resorting to the kinds of violence other cities have seen. Roxboro resident Luther Perkins was in Raleigh Saturday night and saw the...
text:
More than 100 people turned out Sunday afternoon for an quickly-organized
march through Uptown Roxboro to protest the killing of George Floyd in
Minneapolis and to prove that Roxboro residents can protest injustice without
resorting to the kinds of violence other cities have seen.

Roxboro resident Luther Perkins was in Raleigh Saturday night and saw the
destruction that took place after peaceful protests turned violent. He came
home determined to keep that kind of violence from happening here.

"I want people to understand that their voices can be heard without the kinds
of things we've been seeing happen in other places," Perkins said before
Sunday's rally. "We can get together peacefully  all of us  and work toward
the kind of positive change we want."

Perkins announced plans for the rally on Facebook and word spread throughout
the community during the day on Sunday.

The Roxboro Police Department asked permission to participate and Mayor
Merilyn Newell asked Perkins if the city's elected leaders could participate.
Both groups were represented Sunday afternoon, along with members of BASIC 
Brothers and Sisters In Conversation  and the Person County Board of
Education.

But most of the crowd were ordinary citizens who turned out for the rally to
protest what some called "systemic racism and white privilege."

In remarks to the crowd before the march, Perkins said Roxboro residents have
a chance to "show that we are more than people think we are."

He said violence helps nothing.

"You can look at the places where there has been violence and see the hole
they have dug for themselves," Perkins said.

Roxboro Chief of Police David Hess deplored Floyd's killing at the hands of a
Minneapolis police officer. The confrontation was caught on videotape and that
officer has now been charged with third-degree murder.

"George Floyd's life mattered. What condemn what happened. We condemn this
officer and the actions he took in Minneapolis. We will not accept that kind
of behavior by any member of the Roxboro Police Department," Hess said.

He encouraged the peaceful nature of Sunday's protest. "That's why we want to
walk with you today," Hess said.

Rev. Larry McDonald, pastor of Allen's Chapel Church, also expressed a desire
to see controversial issues like racism addressed peacefully. McDonald went to
college with George Floyd's aunt and uncle. He said he spoke with them
Thursday night and they were urging communities not to engage in the kinds of
violent protests which were beginning to flare up.

Newell, Roxboro's mayor, said peaceful marches like Sunday's event create a
blueprint for how communities can work out differences.

"Peace and justice are the only logical conclusions," Newell said.

title: Peaceful Roxboro march protests Floyd killing
html:
More than 100 people turned out Sunday afternoon for an quickly-organized march through Uptown Roxboro to protest the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis and to prove that Roxboro residents can protest injustice without resorting to the kinds of violence other cities have seen.

Roxboro resident Luther Perkins was in Raleigh Saturday night and saw the destruction that took place after peaceful protests turned violent. He came home determined to keep that kind of violence from happening here.

"I want people to understand that their voices can be heard without the kinds of things we've been seeing happen in other places," Perkins said before Sunday's rally. "We can get together peacefully – all of us – and work toward the kind of positive change we want."

Perkins announced plans for the rally on Facebook and word spread throughout the community during the day on Sunday.

The Roxboro Police Department asked permission to participate and Mayor Merilyn Newell asked Perkins if the city's elected leaders could participate. Both groups were represented Sunday afternoon, along with members of BASIC – Brothers and Sisters In Conversation – and the Person County Board of Education.

But most of the crowd were ordinary citizens who turned out for the rally to protest what some called "systemic racism and white privilege."

In remarks to the crowd before the march, Perkins said Roxboro residents have a chance to "show that we are more than people think we are."

He said violence helps nothing.

"You can look at the places where there has been violence and see the hole they have dug for themselves," Perkins said.

Roxboro Chief of Police David Hess deplored Floyd's killing at the hands of a Minneapolis police officer. The confrontation was caught on videotape and that officer has now been charged with third-degree murder.

"George Floyd's life mattered. What condemn what happened. We condemn this officer and the actions he took in Minneapolis. We will not accept that kind of behavior by any member of the Roxboro Police Department," Hess said.

He encouraged the peaceful nature of Sunday's protest. "That's why we want to walk with you today," Hess said.

Rev. Larry McDonald, pastor of Allen's Chapel Church, also expressed a desire to see controversial issues like racism addressed peacefully. McDonald went to college with George Floyd's aunt and uncle. He said he spoke with them Thursday night and they were urging communities not to engage in the kinds of violent protests which were beginning to flare up.

Newell, Roxboro's mayor, said peaceful marches like Sunday's event create a blueprint for how communities can work out differences.

"Peace and justice are the only logical conclusions," Newell said.
